ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned A LOT about the social functions of emotions and the role that it plays in our lives. I also learned how to better read scholarly sources and psychology journals which was helpful for many of my other classes as well.
Learned so much about how emotions serve social functions! Super interesting because I had never thought about the actual function of emotions before.
I learned a lot about different emotions, how emotions conceptualized in the research, and how they affect our social lives.

I think the greatest strength of this class is it teaches you to dig for nuance in the psych work you read and the way you think. What are the boundary conditions? What do these boundary conditions tell us? This type of thinking is something that feels deeply valuable.

Learned how to closely read psychology papers and apply thinking to specified questions, look for ways to disagree with findings, challenge methodology, and think about the bigger impact. Learned how to engage with different theories around emotions and how impactful they are in our lives.
I learned how to think critically about emotions

I learned how to read psychology research articles, think of real life examples to apply the theories we discussed in class, how to think about emotions in relational/social contexts, how to respond thoughtfully to articles, and so much more.

The course gave us skills in evaluating the function, role, and experience of social emotions in society. This was a surprisingly applicable course, and I felt that I learnt a lot about myself and why people feel and act the way they do. We also learnt how to assess holes in the scientific literature and produce novel psychological theory.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was AMAZING because Professor Clark is just great. She loves to hear student input and the class is largely discussion-based. I got to know my fellow classmates better, as well as Professor Clark. The workload was very reasonable and the class was very enjoyable all around.
Overall great course. However, the prompts for the assignments (only 3 10-page papers) got a little repetitive, so that could perhaps be changed.
prof. is AMAZING

The course material was very interesting and always fun to discuss in class. The readings and assignments were manageable, which was great. It could have been more organized in terms of the scheduling of assignments on the syllabus, but overall the class was good.

Strengths: Really interesting papers and incorporation of student contribution/thoughts from reading responses 
Weaknesses: Not enough structure to the class meetings

It is a fantastic course. If I were to give it any small critique, it is that sometimes I felt we missed opportunities to dig deeper into ideas. It can fall into various students giving individual examples of a phenomenon without pushing further. However, when this depth is reached, it is wonderful.

I loved the reading responses every week because you were reading a variety of papers to broaden your knowledge. I liked the questions for the papers that asked you to include your own thinking about a topic, not just do research and summarize. I don't have anything I would really change.

I absolutely loved the course! I wouldnt change one thing. I think Professor Clark should keep her paper policy where we pick which 3 we wanted to do and when. This was extremely helpful when managing busy weeks and midterms/finals!! I also really liked how she allowed us to guide the conversations ourselves to any topics that fascinated us

This course is amazing! It was one of my favorite psychology courses and probably courses at Yale. Professor Clark does so much to make the discussion engaging, exciting, and relevant. The papers are interesting and broad so you can chose topics of interests for you to focus on. The readings were great and I looked forward each week coming to class to discuss them.

Professor Clark is incredible, and the format was engaging. The discussions were always great, and I started to look forward to this class every week. Some of the assignments were a bit badly formed, and some more thought could be given to the breadth and depth balance of the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There was a great level of engagement because we had a live discussion, and didn't just watch a lecture and then come discuss it. I liked this format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, Professor Clark is incredibly wise and this was a particularly rewarding course
Absolutely recommend! Super interesting topics that lead to really fun discussions. Also, Dr. Clark is an amazing person and teacher, and she truly wants her students to do well!
YES
Yes! I recommend this class if you're interested in emotions and/or social psychology. The material is very interesting to learn and discuss.

Definitely, I loved this course and learned so much through the discussions. Professor Clark organized great lectures that really allowed students to form their own opinions and talk to each other about them in a comfortable environment.

Yes I would definitely recommend. Professor Clark is such a wonderful professor who is one of the top in her field. It was a great way to explore different topics without feeling like you were going to say the wrong thing.

YES! Take this class! You get to have fascinating conversations about emotions that you probably have never deeply reflected on. This class really opens your mind and helps you understand yourself and others better. The class was such a delight that it didnt even feel too much like work. The papers can be really fun since you can develop your own theories and thoughts  about emotions

Yes! For sure take this class, even if you are not a psychology major. I would say just be prepared for a lot of writing. We have three papers which are 8-10 pages, and 2 reading responses per week. But all of the assignments are engaging and I highly recommend even with this writing load.
yes! Take any course with Margaret Clark, she's an incredible instructor and truly cares about student learning and success.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: None
Virtual seminar
Office hour meetings with professor
Just the virtual synchronous seminar.
There were no others.
